Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 42470 
November 2008 
 
 
 
Improving Connectivity and Destination Management 
of Cultural and Natural Resources in the South Asia 
Subregion 
(Financed by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under 
the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership 
Facility)  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank  
  SASEC  –  South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance  
  TWG  –  tourism working group 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors  –  Multisector (water supply, sanitation, and 
waste management; industry and trade; 
agriculture and natural resources) 
Subsectors  –  Integrated, industry, environment and 
biodiversity  
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional 
cooperation, capacity development 
Subthemes  –  Fostering physical infrastructure development,  
and  institutional development 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations Group 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  H. Kim, Urban Development Division, SARD 
   
Team leader  G. Cezayirli, Principal Urban Development Specialist, SARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB), through the South Asia Regional Cooperation Strategy 
and Program (2006–2008)1 has reaffirmed its commitment to supporting regional cooperation in 
tourism with significant capacity to contribute to sustainable and inclusive economic growth in the 
subregion.  A  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Improving  Connectivity  and  Destination 
Management of Cultural and Natural Resources in the South Asia subregion has been included in 
ADB’s 2008 assistance pipeline. The TA concept was first discussed with all participating countries at 
the ninth meeting of the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) tourism working 
group (TWG)2 in Delhi in May 2008. Subsequently, ADB missions visited Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, 
and  Nepal  to  further  discuss  and  finalize  the  scope,  costs,  financing,  and  implementation 
arrangements of the TA. The proposed TA3 forms an important intervention in the process of a long-
term partnership between ADB and the TWG countries for developing environmentally- and culturally-
sustainable, and socially inclusive tourism to catalyze economic growth and reduce poverty in the 
subregion. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  South Asia is one of the poorest regions of the world. However, the region has rich and 
diverse natural and cultural heritage assets and major Buddhist sites, positioning it as a Buddhist 
heartland and one of the most attractive nature- and culture-based tourism destinations in the world. 
The region has tremendous potential for developing tourism that can be used to expand economic 
opportunities,  generate  employment,  and  raise  incomes,  particularly  for  the  subregion’s  poor. 
Harnessing the full potential of tourism in the subregion requires coordinated approaches to tourism 
expansion  and  integrated  development  and  promotion  of  the  subregion’s  tourism  assets  by 
participating countries.  
 
3.  Since the formation of the TWG in 2001 under the SASEC Program, ADB and TWG countries 
have identified tourism as one of the priority areas for cooperation. In 2004, the TWG, with ADB 
support, prepared and adopted a subregional tourism development plan that provided a strategic 
framework for coordinated tourism initiatives among participating countries. More recently, the TWG 
perceived the need for more tangible outcomes and requested ADB’s financial support for the joint 
development of tourism infrastructure. An ADB-funded regional TA,4 which was implemented recently, 
developed a tourism infrastructure road map comprising a number of multi-country tourism circuits as 
a framework for phased infrastructure development. The TA determined the overall infrastructure 
requirements in these multi-country tourism circuits and undertook a prefeasibility evaluation of priority 
subprojects along the high-potential circuits, with a focus on the subregion’s Buddhist heartland and 
natural and cultural heritage sites. The purpose of the integrated development of multi-country tourism 
circuits is to link the complementary and contiguous tourism attractions of the subregion’s countries 
that otherwise might not be sufficient to attract high levels of tourist arrivals on an individual basis. 
ADB  has  already  initiated  the  processing  of  the  subregional  investment  project  (the  Project)  5 
comprising high-priority investments along the selected multi-country circuits. However, advanced 
levels of cooperation in tourism and the integrated development of tourism infrastructure in multi-
country circuits need to be supported with a number of additional complementary interventions.  
 
4.   Need to Sustain Cooperation in Subregional Tourism Development. There is a need to 
sustain cooperation in tourism in the subregion beyond the proposed TA and the forthcoming Project. 
                                                 
1   ADB. 2006. South Asia Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program (2006–2008).Manila                                                                        
2  The South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation TWG includes Bangladesh, Bhutan, India’s north and northeastern 
states, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.   
3   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on October 2008.  
4  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Tourism Development Project. 
Manila (TA 6362-REG, approved on 13 December, for $1.0 million).     
5  The “Project” refers to the subregional loan/grant project for “Improving Connectivity and Destination Infrastructure for 
Subregional Tourism Development” for which loan fact-finding missions were completed.

2 
The subregional tourism development plan of 2004 proved to be an effective instrument in facilitating 
cooperation and coordinated tourism actions towards common goals in the subregion. However, there 
is a need for periodic adjustments to the plan in order to maintain its relevance in the context of the 
evolving needs as highlighted by the eighth TWG meeting in 2007. Adjustments to the plan are 
required in light of a new stage of subregional cooperation for joint infrastructure development and to 
incorporate the findings of the recent TA, especially the subregional tourism infrastructure road map 
that was developed and endorsed under the TA.  
 
5.   Need to Streamline Cross-Border Tourist Movement. While many of the key border points 
between the participating countries and on the selected multi-country circuits are open to tourist travel, 
and subregional tourism growth is not directly dependent upon immediate action to facilitate cross-
border travel, the benefits will significantly increase in the long run if cross-border travel is further 
streamlined. Possible actions to promote cross-border travel include, depending on the specific border 
point, streamlining visa issuance procedures, facilitating tourist vehicle movements, and coordinating 
border opening times and duration. The participating countries recognize these issues and they are at 
various stages of addressing them. There is a need to (i) continue constructive dialogue among the 
TWG countries to address issues that potentially could hamper realization of the full benefits of 
integrated development of multi-country tourism circuits, and (ii) develop an agreed-upon plan of 
coordinated action to facilitate cross-border tourist movement.  
 
6.  Need for Subregional Action for Market Expansion. The viability of the Project and other 
investments being made to enhance subregional tourism will ultimately depend upon the number of 
visitors to the subregion, which will, to a significant extent, be influenced by the level of the target 
markets’ awareness of the subregion’s tourism assets. The TWG countries recognize this and have 
supported subregional marketing initiatives in the past. There is a need for continuous and collective 
marketing and promotion of the subregion as a unique destination. This is especially important for the 
multi-country tourism circuits to be developed under the forthcoming Project. The statistics show that 
many tourists are combining several countries in their trip to the subregion, which is the primary 
rationale for supporting multi-country circuit development under the forthcoming Project. There is a 
need to develop measures to complement ongoing interventions to enhance  demand from current 
and new markets for existing and potential multi-country circuits, and the subregion as a whole, 
especially high-value Western and Asian markets, and domestic and intraregional markets.   
 
7.  Need for Subregional Knowledge and Experience Sharing. While there are substantial 
capacity constraints to protecting, developing, managing, and promoting tourism destinations and 
assets of cultural and natural importance in the subregion, there are also specific examples of good 
practices that can be used for further replication, including the excellent management of sensitive 
destinations such as natural and cultural heritage sites. In some cases, community–government–
industry partnerships are promoted to support the development of inclusive and sustainable nature-
based tourism. There is also widespread enthusiasm for sharing knowledge and experience among 
the participating countries. There is a need to complement national-level, capacity-building efforts with 
subregional experience and knowledge-sharing activities that focus on sustainable and inclusive 
development and management of nature- and culture-based tourism destinations.  
 
8.  Need to Enhance Preparedness for the Subregional Investment Project. There is a need 
to assist the participating countries to enhance their capacity and readiness for implementing the 
forthcoming Project, both at the subregional and national levels. Implementation of the Project will 
require  formation  of  a  subregional  task  force—comprising  members  of  the  TWG  and  key 
implementing  agencies  of  the  Project—to  monitor  and  provide  policy  guidance  on  project 
implementation. Support is needed to enable to the task force to perform its mandate. In addition, 
effective  and  timely  implementation  of  the  forthcoming  Project  will  require  support  for  individual 
countries to enhance their project management and implementation capacities, and to undertake 
project start-up activities in a timely manner. There is a need to provide bridging assistance to the 
participating countries for enhanced project preparedness.

3 
9.  At this stage of subregional cooperation in tourism, and given the demonstrated efforts of 
participating countries to cooperate on joint infrastructure development, there is need for further 
support to enable continuous and focused subregional dialogue, and ensure the effectiveness of the 
forthcoming Project. The TA is required to (i) enable sustainable cooperation among participating 
countries for subregional tourism development; (ii) promote dialogue and actions for streamlining 
cross-border tourist travel; (iii) assist in collective marketing and promotion of the subregion’s tourism 
assets, with a greater focus on the multi-country tourism circuits that will be developed under the 
Project;  (iv)  provide  for  subregional  experience  and  knowledge  sharing  for  stakeholder  capacity 
building in the sustainable protection and management of natural and cultural heritage sites of tourism 
importance, including exposure to innovative approaches (e.g., partnerships between community–
public–private sectors); and (v) help enhance the preparedness of the participating countries at both 
the national and subregional levels for the timely and efficient implementation of the Project.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The expected impact of the proposed TA is the enhanced positioning of the subregion in both 
intraregional and international markets as one of the world’s leading destinations for spiritual-, nature-, 
and culture-based tourism. This will be achieved by facilitating expanded subregional dialogue for 
collective  action  and  capacity  building  for  enhanced  subregional  tourism  development  that  is 
environmentally- and culturally-sustainable, and socially inclusive.  
 
11.  The expected outputs of the proposed TA are: (i) a deepened subregional dialogue guided by 
an updated and focused subregional tourism plan and action agenda; (ii) an increased awareness of 
cross-border issues and ongoing, concerted efforts based on a broadly agreed-upon plan of action to 
streamline  cross-border  tourist  travel;  (iii)  enhanced  capacity  for  collective  marketing  of  the 
subregion’s  assets  and  ongoing  efforts  for  marketing  and  promotion  based  on  a  strategy  and 
expansion plan that focuses on the selected multi-country circuits; (iv) improved capacities of the 
public sector, communities, and the tourism industry for sustainable and inclusive management of 
natural and cultural heritage sites and Buddhist circuits; and (v) enhanced preparedness of national-
level stakeholders to manage and implement the Project in an effective and timely manner. The TA 
will  include  the  TWG  countries,  i.e.,  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  India,  Nepal,  and  Sri  Lanka  with  the 
exception of output (v), which will only include the TWG countries participating in the Project.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The proposed TA will include the following components.     
 
13.  Support for Effective Subregional Cooperation. This component will strengthen the basis 
for sustainable subregional cooperation. The subregional tourism plan of 2004 will be updated to 
make it a living document. The plan will be realigned and its scope will be redefined to incorporate the 
findings of recent regional TA and joint infrastructure development efforts based on a framework of 
multi-country tourism circuits. An updated and focused tourism development matrix and action plan 
will also be prepared in consultation with TWG members to provide an effective tool for use by the 
TWG to track the progress of coordinated efforts for advanced subregional tourism development.     
 
14.  Streamlining  Cross-border  Tourist  Movement. This component will help in providing a 
platform for dialogue and collective action among participating countries for smoother cross-border 
tourist movement. An assessment of non physical cross-border issues in each multi-country tourism 
circuit will be made and discussed to raise awareness and garner support among the participating 
countries to overcome obstacles. Options for solutions will be developed in consultation with and 
considering the ongoing plans and efforts of participating countries. An overall time-bound action plan 
and  individual  country  agendas  will  be  prepared  to  streamline  cross-border  tourist  movement. 
Coordination and synergies will be established with other relevant initiatives in the subregion.

4 
15.  Action Plan for Market Expansion.  This component aims to ensure collective efforts for 
marketing the subregion’s tourism assets and especially the multi-country tourism circuits that will be 
developed under the forthcoming Project. The  component will support (i) a market assessment and 
additional research into new markets that build on existing market flows; (ii) marketing products and 
communications measures to enhance demand from current and potential new markets, especially 
high-value Western and Asian markets, and increase domestic and intraregional demand; and (iii)  a 
time-framed marketing action plan and supporting institutional arrangements for implementation that 
give special attention to the participation of the subregion’s private sector. Some of the activities will 
likely include: (i) developing a South Asia manual for the travel trade to feature the subregion’s natural 
and cultural assets and give greater focus to selected multi-country circuits, (ii) a media and travel 
trade familiarization program to promote the subregion’s tourism assets, (iii) participation in selected 
trade fairs and sales missions in source markets, (iv) sustained website management, (v) preparation 
of updated South Asia promotional materials, and (vi) design and implementation of a marketing and 
promotion monitoring and evaluation system to assess performance against key indicators.  
 
16.  Subregional Experience and Knowledge Sharing. This component will support capacity 
building and human resource development for ensuring (i) the sustainability of the natural and cultural 
heritage sites of tourism importance, with a greater focus on the multi-country circuits to be developed 
under the Project; and (ii) increased cooperation among and benefits to the subregion’s communities 
from the nature- and culture-based tourism interventions, including partnerships among the public and 
private sectors, and communities. The component will complement national-level capacity-building 
efforts  through  experience-  and  knowledge-sharing  activities,  including  study  tours,  workshops, 
seminars, and exposure to best practices within and outside the subregion. These activities will target 
public sector officials, community leaders, and industry members who are collectively responsible for 
protecting, developing, and managing the sites in selected multi-country tourism circuits.  
 
17.  Enhanced Project Preparedness and Management. This component will promote effective 
management and timely implementation of the Project. It will support the participating countries at the 
subregional  and  national  levels.  At  the  subregional  level,  assistance  will  be  provided  to  the 
subregional  task  force  that  will  be  formed  to  oversee  progress  and  provide  policy  guidance  in 
implementing  the  Project.  The  task  force  will  be  supported  in  performing  annual  consolidated 
subregional reviews of country components, advising as necessary on overall implementation issues 
and coordinating implementation of the Project with the proposed TA for consistency in intended 
outcomes. At the national level, support will be provided to the participating countries to develop their 
capacity  for  project  management  and  to  undertake  project  start-up  activities,  including  advance 
actions for timely procurement as needed. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $2.4 million. An amount of $2,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation 
and Integration Financing Partnership Facility. The governments of Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, 
and Sri Lanka will provide $400,000 equivalent to cover the costs of counterpart staff and office 
accommodation and facilities in their respective countries. Detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  For all components listed above, except Enhanced Project Preparedness and Management, 
ADB will execute the TA. The TWG and the subregional task force will act as the steering committee 
to oversee and guide TA implementation. The TA will be managed by ADB’s South Asia Department 
Urban Development Division. National tourism organizations will be the TA focal agencies in each 
participating  country  responsible  for  providing  the  required  national  inputs  for  the  TA  and  will 
coordinate  with  representatives  of  central  and  local  government  agencies,  nongovernment 
organizations, the private sector, and the tourism industry. For the component Enhanced Project 
Preparedness and Management, the focal agencies will include the following in each respective

5 
country: Bangladesh, Department of Archeology; India, Sikkim’s Tourism Department Nepal, Civil 
Aviation Authority and Lumbini Development Trust.     
 
20.  The  TA  will  commence  in  March  2009.  The  first  four  components  listed  above  will  be 
implemented over 2 years until March 2011. Enhanced Project Preparedness and Management will 
be implemented over 8 months until November 2009. The TA will require about 161 person-months of 
consulting  services  (11  person-months  international  and  150  person-months  national).  ADB  will 
engage consulting firms and an individual consultant in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007 as amended from time to time). National tourism organizations will provide office 
space  and  facilities,  and  suitably-qualified  counterpart  staff  for  the  consultants  to  support 
implementation of the first four components and the subregional aspects of the Enhanced Project 
Preparedness  and  Management  component.    At  the  national  level  of  the  Enhanced  Project 
Preparedness and Management component, the key agencies involved in the implementation of the 
Project (listed in para. 19) will be responsible for providing office space, logistics, and counterpart staff. 
 
21.  A consulting firm, comprising a team of international and national consultants, will be recruited 
using the quality- and cost-based method of selection to carry out the first four components. The team 
will possess expertise in subregional tourism planning, marketing and promotion, travel facilitation, 
and  tourism-related  capacity  building  and  human  resource  development.  The  consultant  for  the 
Enhanced  Project  Preparedness  and  Management  component  at  the  subregional  level  will  be 
recruited individually. An international tourism planner and infrastructure development specialist will 
be engaged as a subregional tourism advisor to support the subregional task force during project 
implementation.  At  the  national  level  of  the  Enhanced  Project  Preparedness  and  Management 
component,  the  consultants  will  be  recruited  as  national  firms,  one  for  each  of  the  countries 
participating in the Project. The teams will posses expertise in project management, procurement, 
airport engineering, civil, electrical, and structural engineering, cultural heritage and conservation, 
ecotourism, community participation, and safeguards (See Appendix 3 for outline terms of reference). 
 
22.  The consultant team recruited to carry out the first four components will submit an inception 
report containing an approach and work plan within 1 month of the start of the TA. This will provide 
linkages with the Project to ensure consistency in outcomes. An interim report to be submitted within 6 
months of the TA start will contain a (i) cross-border issues paper; (ii) position paper for revising the 
subregional tourism plan; (iii) marketing strategy; and (iv) subregional training plan, including a needs 
assessment. The first annual report, which will be submitted within one year of the TA start and will be 
reviewed by the TWG and subregional task force, will provide (i) a revised subregional tourism plan, (ii) 
an action agenda for streamlining cross-border tourist movement, (iii) a market expansion plan, and 
(iv) an update on the status of subregional experience and knowledge sharing. The second year will 
focus on implementation of action agendas and establish systems and procedures for uninterrupted 
implementation of subregional agendas following the conclusion of the TA. Quarterly progress reports 
will  be  submitted  in  the  second  year  followed  by  a  second  annual  report  documenting  all  TA 
accomplishments as compared to the original objectives and scope. The consultant recruited for 
Enhanced  Project  Preparedness  and  Management  at  the  subregional  level  will  provide  reports 
outlining the outcome of each annual meeting of the subregional task force, while the consultants for 
this component at the national level submit an inception report, interim progress report, and a final 
report within 1, 4, and 8 months of the TA’s start respectively. Disbursements under the TA will accord 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, amended from time to time). 
  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 for Improving Connectivity and Destination Management 
of Cultural and Natural Resources in the South Asia Subregion to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund  under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility.

  3.  Meetings, Workshops, and Training c   
         a.   Subregional Task Force Meetings    150.0
             b.   Regional Dialogue for Cross-border Facilitation    60.0
             c.  Subregional  Learning  Events  (Workshops,  Study    240.0
Tours, and Courses)    
             d.   Marketing Events and Materials    150.0
  4.  Miscellaneous Administration Costs, including Reports    40.0
and Communications d
  5.  Contingencies    180.0
      Subtotal     2,000.0
   
B.   Participating Governments Financing e          
1.    Office Accommodation and Logistics     200.0
2.    Remuneration and Per Diem of Counterpart Staff    200.0
                 Subtotal    400.0
   
              Total    2,400.0
a
  Administered by the Asian Development Bank.  
b  
Includes  surveys  and  investigations  for  Enhanced  Project  Preparedness  and  Management  component 
(national level) in countries participating in the subregional investment project. Payment for surveys will be 
made through the selected consulting firm.  
c 
These  include  five  subregional  task  force  meetings,  four  regional  dialogue  meetings,  and  subregional 
knowledge and experience sharing and learning events. For the latter, a detailed “subregional knowledge- and 
experience-sharing and learning program” will be developed within first 6 months of the technical assistance. 
The selected events and programs under the subregional knowledge-sharing and learning program might be 
delivered by a suitable partner agency on a contractual basis, based on the detailed program proposals and 
subject to Asian Development Bank and tourism working group endorsement.   
d
  This includes report and communication costs. 
e  
This will be through in-kind contributions by Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage consulting firms and individual consultants 
in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007 as amended from time to time). 
Consultants will be recruited in several packages to undertake various components of the technical 
assistance (TA). They will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with the 
exception of package 2, which will be recruited individually. The type of technical proposals to be 
used for packages 1 and 3 are bio-data technical proposals. 
 
(i)  Package 1. A consulting firm, comprising a team of international and national consultants, 
will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection method to carry out the following 
components  described  in  the  TA  report:  Support  for  Effective  Subregional  Cooperation, 
Streamlining  Cross-border  Tourist  Movement,  Action  Plan  for  Market  Expansion,  and 
Subregional Experience and Knowledge Sharing. The package will require a total of 16 
person-months of consultancy inputs, including 8 person-months international and 8 person-
months national. International consultancy inputs will be in the areas of tourism planning and 
team leadership (2.5 person-months), tourism marketing and promotion (2 person-months), 
tourism-related capacity building and human resource development (1.5 person-months), 
and travel facilitation (2 person-months). National consultancy inputs will be in the areas of 
tourism planning (2 person-months), tourism marketing and promotion (2 person-months), 
travel facilitation (2 person-months), and training (2 person-months). The consultants will 
coordinate closely with and support each other, and also coordinate with the subregional 
tourism advisor, who will be recruited individually. The package will be implemented over 2 
years from March 2009 to March 2011. 
(ii)  Package  2. An international consultant (3 person-months) with expertise in subregional 
tourism infrastructure development and broad-based experience in tourism planning and 
institutional-strengthening aspects will be recruited as subregional tourism advisor for the 
subregional level of the Enhanced Project Preparedness and Management component to 
support  the  subregional  task  force  over  the  implementation  period  of  the  subregional 
investment project.  
(iii)  Packages  3.  The  consultants  for  Enhanced  Project  Preparedness  and  Management 
component at the national level will be recruited as national consulting firms in multiple 
packages for each of the countries participating in the Project. A total of 140 person-months 
of national consultancy inputs will be required in the areas of project management and team 
leadership  (24  person-months);  procurement  (8  person-months);  airport  engineering  (20 
person-months)  civil,  electrical,  and  structural  engineering  (58  person-months);  cultural 
heritage and conservation (5 person-months); ecotourism (7 person-months); community 
participation (8 person-months); and safeguards (10 person-months). These packages will 
be implemented over 8 months from March 2009 to November 2009. 
 
2.  The tasks of consultants under each package are provided below:  
 
A.  Package 1   
 
1.  Support to Sustainable Subregional Dialogue  
3.  This  component  will  be  undertaken  by  international  and  national  tourism  planners  with 
support of other experts as necessary. The tourism planners should have experience in tourism 
planning at a subregional level and exposure to tourism infrastructure development and pro-poor 
and sustainable tourism development principles and practices.

Appendix 3  11 
4.  This component will strengthen the basis for subregional cooperation by making appropriate 
adjustments to the subregional tourism development plan of 2004 in order to maintain its relevance 
in the context of evolving needs and new cooperation in joint infrastructure development. The 
consultants’ tasks will include, but not be limited to the following:  
 
(i)  Review the subregional tourism development plan of 2004, the tourism infrastructure road 
map  prepared  and  endorsed  under  the  TA 1   for  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic 
Cooperation  Tourism  Development  Project,  and  the  proposed  ADB-funded  Project  for 
Improving Connectivity and Destination Infrastructure for Subregional Tourism Development 
(the Project). Review the institutional improvement action agendas for each country under 
the proposed Project. 
(ii)  Consult with members of the tourism working group (TWG) and the subregional task force to 
consolidate views on the required adjustments to the plan. 
(iii)  Closely work with experts on (a) subregional cross-border facilitation, (b) market expansion, 
and (c) subregional experience and knowledge sharing; and coordinate with the national-
level institutional and capacity-building experts under the Project.  
(iv)  Review the ongoing efforts and discussions by ADB, South Asia Subregional Economic 
Cooperation countries, and the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and 
Economic  Cooperation  on  the  envisaged  expansion  of  the  regional  working  group  to 
embrace the Bay of Bengal Initiative Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation in 
regional cooperation in tourism.  
(v)  Provide  a  position  paper  to  describe  the  required  changes  and  adjustments,  and  the 
rationale for them.  
(vi)  Undertake adjustments to the tourism plan of 2004, reflecting the direction of recent studies 
and projects, and ongoing work by other experts under the current regional TA. Provide a 
draft revised plan for review and comments by the TWG and ADB. Incorporate feedback and 
finalize the report. The plan should (a) readjust the scope of subregional cooperation in 
tourism in light of the new stage of cooperation on joint infrastructure development and 
streamlined cross-border tourism; and (b) provide a prioritized plan of activities for short-term, 
mid-term, and long-term subregional cooperation in tourism. The priority activities should be 
targeted to support the effectiveness of the subregional investment project. Develop a time-
bound development matrix to provide a tool for structured TWG meetings and review the 
TWG’s progress in implementing the plan.  
(vii)  Assess the requirements for coordination and communications to implement the plan and 
sustain subregional cooperation. Develop and propose simple, yet effective, communications 
techniques and coordination mechanisms that limit the time and resources required of TWG 
members and national tourism organizations and other stakeholders 
 
2.  Streamlining Cross-border Tourist Movement 
5.  This component will be undertaken by international national travel facilitation experts who 
have experience in cross-border tourist travel in a regional tourism context. They will supported by 
other experts under this package as necessary. 
 
6.  The component aims to facilitate and streamline cross-border travel and tourism with a 
special focus on the multi-country circuits included in the Project as well as the tourism infrastructure 
road map developed under the TA for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Tourism 
Development Project. The consultants’ tasks will include but not be limited to the following:  
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Tourism Development 
Project. Manila (TA 6362-REG, approved on 13 December, for $1.0 million).

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  Review the existing arrangements on key border points related to tourism and travel activities, 
especially border points located along the multi-country circuits to be developed under the 
Project and those multi-country circuits included in the tourism infrastructure road map. 
(ii)  Assess issues related to the smooth movement of tourist and related services across these 
border points, in terms of tourist travel and immigration procedures. 
(iii)  Assess the participating governments’ plans and ongoing efforts to address the issues and to 
streamline cross-border travel. 
(iv)  Prepare an issues paper for discussion in the regional dialogue forum. The issues paper 
should draw the attention of the TWG and garner political and administrative support for 
nationally-driven actions (already initiated by the participating countries themselves) towards 
cross-border  travel  facilitation.  The  paper  should  describe  the  (a)  issues  and  their 
consequences in terms of subregional tourism development, (b) options for solutions for 
consideration by the governments, and (c) the benefits of addressing these issues. 
(v)  Develop, in consultation with governments, a prioritized action agenda to address the issues 
and  facilitate  and  streamline  cross-border  travel.  The  actions  required  and  responsible 
parties should also be identified.  
(vi)  Assist in organizing regular regional dialogue forums with the TWG and side meetings with 
other stakeholders, prepare separate agendas for each meeting on the basis of the action 
plan  and  agreed-upon  priorities  to  keep  the  dialogue  alive  and  elicit  action  towards 
addressing cross-border issues. 
 
3.  Subregional Action Plan for Market Expansion 
7.  This component will be undertaken by international and national tourism marketing and 
promotion experts with experience in multi-country tourism destination marketing and promotion. 
The experts will be supported by other experts under this package as necessary. 
 
8.  The component aims to enhance the positioning of the subregion and, more importantly, the 
multi-country  circuits  being  developed  in  the  target  markets  through  collective  marketing  and 
promotion of the subregion’s tourism assets. The consultants’ tasks will include, but not be limited to 
the following:  
 
(i)  Undertake an updated market assessment based on existing and projected tourism market 
flows, especially as the result of interventions including the subregional investment project.  
(ii)  Identify target market segments (geographic- and interest-based), both international and 
intraregional. 
(iii)  Review  the  national  marketing  initiatives  and  the  coordinated  marketing  efforts  of 
participating countries since 2004. 
(iv)  Building on the above work, develop measures and a strategy to enhance demand from 
current and potential source markets for the multi-country tourism circuits to be developed 
under the subregional investment project and those circuits identified under the tourism 
infrastructure road map, and the subregion as a whole.  
(v)  Develop a five-year market expansion plan with a priority on multi-country circuits and assist 
in preparing various relevant materials, events, and programs. These may likely include (a) 
preparing updated South Asia tourism promotion materials, (b) helping in active website 
management, (c) organizing select trade fairs, (d) developing a South Asia manual, (e) 
organizing  a  visiting  media  program,  and  (f)  conducting  exposure  and  familiarization 
programs for travel agents to promote the subregion’s tourism assets. Assist in monitoring 
progress and take action on issues as required.

Appendix 3  13 
4.  Subregional Experience and Knowledge Sharing 
9.  This component will be undertaken by an international capacity building and human resource 
development specialist with experience in tourism-related capacity building; and a national training 
expert with experience in designing and conducting international training programs on sustainable 
and pro-poor tourism, with a focus on ecotourism and cultural tourism destination development, 
management, and promotion. The consultants will be supported by other experts as necessary. 
 
10.  The component will supplement national-level capacity-building efforts under the Project with 
subregional-level learning. The consultants’ tasks will include, but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Undertake,  in  conjunction  with  national  capacity-building  efforts  under  the  Project,  an 
assessment  of  training  needs  and  target  groups  for  environmentally-  and  culturally-
sustainable planning, development, and management of nature-, culture-, and spiritual-based 
tourism destinations with a greater focus on the multi-country circuits and destinations to be 
developed under the Project and tourism infrastructure road map.  
(ii)  Identify the high-priority target groups in consultation with the TWG and other stakeholders 
from the public sector, communities, and the tourism industry that have an impact on the 
quality of management and sustainability of tourism destinations. 
(iii)  Identify inspiring best practices, both within and outside of the subregion, in sustainable 
management of nature- and culture-based tourism destinations. 
(iv)  Identify any training institute or development partner, either within or outside of the subregion, 
with  sound  experience  managing  training  programs  in  the  above  areas  and  arrange  a 
partnership with them in case their involvement is sought in delivering learning programs. 
(v)  Design a subregional experience- and knowledge-sharing and learning program involving 
subregional workshops, study tours, and/or training courses for various groups. The tentative 
topics to be covered, among others, include (a) planning, protection, and management of 
cultural and world heritage sites; (b) sustainable management of nature-based destinations; 
(c) visitor and tourist management of spiritually-important destinations; (d) community-based 
tourism modalities and enhanced linkages between communities and major tourism markets; 
and  (e)  innovative  community–public–private  partnerships  in  nature-  and  culture-based 
tourism destination management.     
(vi)  Identify  partner  organizations  (e.g.,  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  [UNICEF], 
nongovernment organizations, and training institutes) that may be involved in conducting 
similar programs and liaise with them for appropriate arrangements. 
(vii)  Develop a system of monitoring the implementation and impact of subregional learning 
programs and discuss the findings in TWG meetings.  
(viii)  Assess the scope for research and dissemination of findings from the learning activities 
above and produce one publication on a priority training topic or a combination of the topics.   
(ix)  Prepare an evaluation report by the end of the subregional learning program.          
 
B.  Package 2: Support to Subregional Task Force 
 
11.  The  component  will  support  the  subregional  task  force  that  will  be  formed  to  oversee 
implementation of the Project at the subregional level. The advisor will work closely with ADB and 
the countries participating in the Project to support the subregional task force as well as coordinate 
between the Project and the proposed regional TA to ensure consistency in the outcomes of the two 
parallel and complementary initiatives. The consultant’s tasks will include, but not be limited to the 
following: 
 
(i)  Review the progress of national projects under the subregional investment project (Project).  
(ii)  Assist in consolidating the national progress reports into a subregional progress report.

14  Appendix 3 
 
(iii)  Assist in organizing annual review meetings and preparing the review reports for the Project.  
(iv)  Assist in identifying any issues that may have a bearing on the overall implementation of the 
Project and advise on addressing the issues. 
(v)  Assist in identifying country projects’ successes and present them to other partners to learn 
from. 
(vi)  Provide hands-on training and support to subregional task force to undertake effective review 
and remedial actions to ensure smooth implementation of the overall Project. 
(vii)  Review TA outputs to avoid overlaps and ensure consistency in outcomes and outputs of the 
two initiatives. Provide feedback to ADB and the TWG and subregional task force about the 
outcome of coordination. Interact with TA consultants as required to address any issues with 
respect to consistency and synchronization of outputs. Ensure full coordination between the 
activities of the Project and the proposed regional TA.    
(viii)  Assist  in  the  continuous  review  of  the  progress  and  implementation  of  the  subregional 
tourism  plan  and  action  agendas  following  the  demobilization  of  the  consultants  under 
package 1. 
 
C.  Package 3: Enhanced Project Readiness  
 
12.  This  component  aims  at  achieving  effective  and  timely  implementation  of  the  national 
projects under the subregional investment Project by extending support to participating countries. 
Support will be targeted to (i) enhancing project management and exposure to ADB procedures in 
project implementation (e.g., procurement); (ii) supporting the planning, investigation, surveys, and 
detailed design of priority packages; and (iii) conducting programs to raise public and community 
awareness of the Project and progress safeguards documentation. The tasks of the consultant 
teams in each participating country will include, but not be limited to the following:      
 
(i)  Assess the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies, and identify the need for 
capacity building for timely and effective implementation of the proposed loans and grant for 
the subregional investment project.  
(ii)   Assist in formation of project management and implementation units with optimal managerial 
and technical personnel structures, and related terms of reference.  
(iii)  Conduct training for key staff to familiarize them with ADB procedures.  
(iv)  Assist in developing project management systems and procedures. 
(v)  Provide hands-on assistance in preparing and finalizing all documentation for the recruitment 
of consultants for project management, detailed design, and construction supervision. 
(vi)  Assist in procurement activities, including: (a) possible advance procurement activities for 
services, goods, and civil works in accordance with ADB guidelines to expedite project start-
up; (b) finalization of contract packages, and their grouping and mode of procurement; and (c) 
identification of fast-track packages that can be undertaken on a priority basis.                
(vii)  Assist  in  undertaking  necessary  engineering  surveys  and  investigations,  and  preparing 
detailed  designs  of  the  priority  subprojects  to  be  implemented  as  the  first  batch  of 
subprojects under the loans and grant. 
(viii)  Design and assist in implementing the initial public awareness programs of the forthcoming 
Project. Undertake, based on the scope of the Project in each country, preparatory activities 
for  fostering  community  participation  in  project  implementation  and  its  benefits  (e.g., 
community mapping, raising awareness of nature- and culture-based tourism, and expanding 
linkages with communities), as well as preparation of safeguard documents.

metadata.Title: Improving Connectivity and Destination Management of Cultural and Natural Resources in the South Asia Subregion (Financed by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility)

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank  
  SASEC  –  South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance  
  TWG  –  tourism working group 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors  –  Multisector (water supply, sanitation, and 
waste management; industry and trade; 
agriculture and natural resources) 
Subsectors  –  Integrated, industry, environment and 
biodiversity  
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional 
cooperation, capacity development 
Subthemes  –  Fostering physical infrastructure development,  
and  institutional development 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations Group 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  H. Kim, Urban Development Division, SARD 
   
Team leader  G. Cezayirli, Principal Urban Development Specialist, SARD
